headline.main: With New Lease on Life, Don't Miss the Fine Print

docs.lead_paragraph: Only if you never watch television, read a newspaper or magazine or listen to comedians can you have escaped the revolution that has occurred in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Three drugs -- Viagra (sildenafil), Levitra (vardenafil) and Cialis (tadalafil) -- have in recent years joined several older and more invasive or involved treatments for this common condition.
docs.snippet: Drugs used to treat erectile dysfunction have helped millions  but many don't know the risks, and others aren't being treated at all.

headline.main: Sometimes It's Better Just to Do Less Harm

docs.lead_paragraph: Hippocrates' injunction to physicians, ''First, do no harm,'' is not always easy to follow. Sometimes doing the right thing medically means risking lesser harm to avoid greater harm. When I first met Larry, he was 40 pounds overweight, hypertensive and in a bind. His internist had just told him that if he could not kick his two-pack-a-day smoking habit, he would surely kill himself.
docs.snippet: Sometimes doing the right thing medically means risking lesser harm to avoid greater harm, especially when it comes to treating addiction.

headline.main: Sex, Sprints, Prostates and Combat: New Studies, Better Lives

docs.lead_paragraph: SMOKING and overeating are bad. Exercise and vegetables are good. Sex is complicated. These are basic truths about fitness and health that all men know, even if they do not always act rationally. While these facts have not changed, research into men's health has gone far beyond them, sometimes providing information that can lead to healthier lives and occasionally leading to conclusions that will raise eyebrows.
docs.snippet: A sampling of some current research into men's health that is not yet common knowledge and not yet part of the health gospel.

headline.main: For Teenagers, a Tweak on 'Just Say No'

docs.lead_paragraph: Some experts say the best way to keep teenage boys away from risky behaviors is to tell them to wait — until they're old enough to know better.
docs.snippet: Some experts say the best way to keep teenage boys away from risky behaviors is to tell them to wait — until they're old enough to know better.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-19-05: DIAGNOSIS

docs.lead_paragraph: 1. Symptoms A wave of nausea swept over the elderly woman as she climbed the stairs of her daughter's home. She hadn't felt well since she left her own tidy studio apartment in Florida the day before. She lowered herself onto the stairs with a quiet moan; her face was pale, her coral pink lipstick faded. ''I'm so sorry, darling,'' she said as her daughter ran into the hallway, ''I threw up on your stairs.'' Embarrassed, she admitted that she hadn't been able to keep anything down since the morning before. She'd thought about not visiting, but at 93, how many more Christmases would she be able to spend with her daughter and grandchildren? ''I kept thinking it was going to go away, but it just hasn't,'' she explained. ''Mother, really!'' the younger woman chided gently as she helped her into her bed and briskly checked her blood pressure. It was high: 200 over 80 (normal is less than 120 over 80). She immediately called her mother's doctor in Florida, who told her to take her mother to the emergency room.
docs.snippet: A 93-year-old patient, even a very capable one, can present unexpected difficulties.
